website_summaries.verdict: For chefs who want a little artistry with their crepes, this is a great choice given its low price point.
pros: Offers many of the same even cooking benefits of cast iron
conducts heat well to create crispy-edged crepes
Can be used for pancakes and omelettes, too
cons: Like cast iron, it requires seasoning before use
Careful cleanup is required to avoid damaging the surface

customer_reviews.title: Pan seems OK but no quality control.
customer_reviews.text: The pan itself seems nice. Somehow, though, the one I received did not have a handle. How was a pan shipped out while missing this pretty important component? It is like buying a car without tires. Any company that can ship out a product in that shape is not one I will use in the future.
customer_reviews.author: Jeff

customer_reviews.title: put it on fire with few drops of oil to season and you are good to go
customer_reviews.text: I bought this pan after enough research about carbon steel pans and I do not regret this purchase. I gave 4 stars only because it does need frequent seasoning for daily use. I bought 2 pans, one of which must have defective and didn't season properly no matter what I did. The second pan works really well. I did potato peel, oil and salt seasoning. I use it for everything including pancakes, crepes, flat bread etc. Wash it with nothing but salt and hot water, dry it, put it on fire with few drops of oil to season and you are good to go. Highly recommend it.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good but small...
customer_reviews.text: Great pan overall and I urge everyone to follow the instructions before, during, and after use. If you do, it will last you aa lifetime and will only get better. One thing that I do not like, however, is the size. I wish they made these about an inch larger in diameter. The largest size is, frankly, kind of small to make stuffed crepes. I understand that if you are making crepe suzette or regular crepes for eating just like that that they are fine. But if you are trying to make a meal and stuff something in side of these, they are kind of small.
customer_reviews.author: John Ash

customer_reviews.title: Good for crepes not dosa.
customer_reviews.text: Good for crepes , not so good for dosa. I bought this to make Indian dosa and after 10 attempts, different techniques and a few different recipes they all stick terribly. I rarely make crepes, did follow all the seasoning instructions so have gone back to using my old large cast iron pan for dosa. Had really hoped to find something less scratchy than my old seasoned cast iron for use on my ceramic top stove that was also not the typical unsafe nonstick pan. These are beautifully designed and made, just not what I had hoped to use it for. Price was great.
customer_reviews.author: M

customer_reviews.title: Is a Flat Pan too Much to Ask For?
customer_reviews.text: The pan design is great. The carbon steel is great. But seriously, how freaking hard is it to make a flat pan? The center of this pan is about 2mm higher than the outer area. This results in the crepe or omelette 1: being thicker around the outer rim than in the center and 2: the food cooking faster around the outer rim because it's hotter than the center due to actually contacting the burner around the rim, but not in the center. Seriously. I just want a pan that's actually flat. Is that too much to ask for?
customer_reviews.author: Bushflyr

customer_reviews.title: Not love at first use
customer_reviews.text: For some reason I thought I was purchasing a nonstick skillet to make healthy crepes, but after receiving my skillet and reading the instructions I saw that this skillet needed treating and oiling prior to cooking. I was not happy at first but decided to keep it, and after several uses, this little skillet has become my go to skillet for much more than crepes (i.e., grilled sandwiches, toast, eggs etc.). I treat it after each washing, wipe off as much oil as possible and I am still able to use cooking spray. A skillet like this will last forever. Well worth the money.
customer_reviews.author: CuteandCurvy

customer_reviews.title: Way better than the non stick versions
customer_reviews.text: I have a de Buyer crepe pan in the same size that is non stick, and this thing is WAY better. After some very simple seasoning (I used a Crisbee stick), crepes just slide around on this thing. I have made the switch to de Buyer carbon steel for other things like searing meats. I still use stainless pans for stuff like sauteeing veggies or making acidic sauces, but these pans are the way to go for most everything else. I only used non stick for things like eggs or crepes before, but there is really no need for those pans now as the carbon steel works much better.
customer_reviews.author: D F

customer_reviews.title: Great quality - perfect for keto crepes!
customer_reviews.text: Crepes made from cream cheese and egg are a staple in my keto diet - so versatile and easy to use as faux breadstuff at breakfast, wrap for a keto-friendly sandwich substitute at lunch, and made into enchiladas at dinner. I've needed a pan that will contain the very liquid batter, and this is perfect. The angle of the edge makes it easy to wedge a spatula under each crepe to turn it. Thank you for the good product and price!
customer_reviews.author: Desert Wryter

customer_reviews.title: GREAT Pan!
customer_reviews.text: Such a great pan. I've had one for YEARS, and gifted this one to my brother since we've gotten so much use out of ours. It's so much more than just a crepe pan (though it is great for that purpose). We use it for just about anything - as a small family who doesn't eat too much meat it's a great size for pan searing a quick chicken breast, breakfast sausages, ham in the morning, hashbrowns, pancakes, fried or scrambled eggs. We really use it every day and it rarely gets put in the cupboard. Super easy to clean - most of the time we just wipe it out with a paper towel if necessary.
customer_reviews.author: Emily McGee

customer_reviews.title: high quality
customer_reviews.text: this is a truly superior pan especially if you are trying to avoid teflon products. making eggs or omelette is easy again. i can make omelette so thin - as a real French! searing meat - fantastic! crepes - OMG! Anything that you would use teflon pan you can do it on this pan and not worry about your health. and because it is naturally non stick the clean up consist of wiping it off. no soaking no scrubbing... but watch the video - it is all there
customer_reviews.author: Scott C.

customer_reviews.title: If you know how to care for high carbon steel, don’t pass this up.
customer_reviews.text: Love this pan so much I use it for lots more than crepes. It’s heat conduction fast and incredible. If you have and use high carbon knives or wok or cast iron, the the care this pan needs won’t put you off. Initial finish takes a few hours of heat and swab lightly with unsalted grease cool and repeat. (I used lard but unsalted butter would do). Eventually it will develop a finish similar to an old well used cast iron and not be so temperamental.
customer_reviews.author: an opinion about everything

customer_reviews.title: Cabon Steel Pros and Cons
customer_reviews.text: Carbon steel is not easy to use. Do the research before buying. This pan maybe built in France but it feels much more like china. It's like they just slapped metal together and hoped it stuck together. I guess 20 bucks made in France is this quality. If you dont care about the looks and maintenance, it's a fantastic value pan but I can't stand a poorly welded handle.

customer_reviews.title: dirty, spotty, rusted

customer_reviews.title: Perks of cast iron at a fraction of the weight.
customer_reviews.text: It's light. It's steel instead of cast iron, so it's much lighter while keeping the amazing heat transfer of steel. Seasoning is easy, you can use metal utensils, and this small pan heats up so much faster than larger skillets. Perfect for making small portions quickly. Your egg(s) will be done on this before your large non-stick can heat up properly. Cleaning is even easier than cast iron since the steel is smooth and wipes down more easily. From unboxing to seasoned and ready to use will only take about five minutes.

If you are serious about cooking, ditch the Teflon and invest in de Buyer cookware (I'm saving up to buy more, piece by piece).

product_meta.title: De Buyer Crepe Pan, Blue Steel, Made in France, 8-Inch Cooking Surface, 9.5-Inches Rim to Rim
product_meta.description: Size:9.5 InchDe Buyer’s French Crepe Pan offers the perfect cooking surface for delicate crepes, caramelizing vegetables, and pan searing meat. Made in France from blue steel that’s easy to season and maintain, it builds up a natural patina with use over time for a foolproof non-stick quality with quick food release. Specially designed with a contoured handle to assist in swirling crepe batter to form perfectly thin, delicate crepes. With a cooking surface of 8-inches and overall surface of 9.5-inches, rim to rim, its shallow depth and flared sides allow delicate foods to be flipped and plated effortless without them breaking apart, from crepes to fluffy pancakes and fried eggs. It works equally well for braising meat, poultry, and fish. A great addition to cooking tools for easy, professional-style cooking in the home kitchen. To season before first use, simply wash in hot, soapy water and scrub with a stiffer brush to remove protective wax coating. Dry thoroughly. Add enough cooking oil to cover the bottom of the pan and heat it over medium flame until smoke appears. Carefully discard the oil and wipe the pan with a paper towel. Voila, the pan is now seasoned and ready for use. To clean after each use, hand wash under hot water with a gentle sponge. Always dry thoroughly. Do not use soap, clean in the dishwasher, or scrub with abrasives, as these will spoil the natural patina buildup and its non-stick quality. Never soak the pan, as it could rust. Should rust occur, simply scrub rust away and repeat the seasoning process. Made in France from blue steel.
